name: Dismissing the truth
description: The dismissal of Gough Whitlam by Governor-General Sir John Kerr is one of the most controversial moments in Australian politics. Whitlam’s rebuttal imploring the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ was immortalised on TV and took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy.

key_work.title: Gough Whitlam - Dismissal
key_work.brief_description: Australia confronted its most controversial and arguably its most far-reaching constitutional crisis when the Governor-General exercised contentious reserve powers to dismiss the Gough Whitlam-led Labor Government on November 11, 1975.

constellations_primary.name: Dismissing the truth

Whitlam’s rebuttal imploring the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ was immortalised on TV and took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy.

start.title: Zelig
start.brief_description: A fictional documentary about the life of human chameleon Leonard Zelig, a man who becomes a celebrity in the 1920s due to his ability to look and act like whoever is around him.

end.title: Forrest Gump
end.creator_credit: Charles Newirth, Steve Starkey, Steve Tisch, Wendy Finerman and The Steve Tisch Company
end.brief_description: Tom Hanks stars as one of the most memorable characters in cinematic history, Forrest Gump, the big-hearted man who was there in the biggest moments in American history. Directed by Robert Zemeckis and written by Eric Roth won six Academy Awards.

constellations_other.name: Quirky, eccentric, charming
constellations_other.description: The eponymous character of Malcolm (1986) is a kind and gentle young man obsessed with trams and making gadgets. Such charming and eccentric figures have a long lineage in screen history.

constellations_other.name: Nadia Tass
constellations_other.description: Comedic and cult classics take centre stage in Nadia Tass' career.

links.description: When Forrest Gump was released in 1994, CGI had developed to the point of facilitating near seamless visual effects. CGI and greenscreen tech allowed the fictional Forrest to interact with real historical figures including John F Kennedy and John Lennon.

end.title: Tom Cruise as Ironman - Deepfake Theater

constellations_other.name: Dismissing the truth
constellations_other.description: The dismissal of Gough Whitlam by Governor-General Sir John Kerr is one of the most controversial moments in Australian politics. Whitlam’s rebuttal imploring the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ was immortalised on TV and took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy.

links.description: Deepfake technology allows professionals and fans alike to recontextualise and remix moving image works. After it was rumoured that Tom Cruise may have played Tony Stark/Iron Man, Deepfake Theatre made it happen, superimposing him into iconic moments from the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

start.title: Gough Whitlam - Dismissal
start.brief_description: Australia confronted its most controversial and arguably its most far-reaching constitutional crisis when the Governor-General exercised contentious reserve powers to dismiss the Gough Whitlam-led Labor Government on November 11, 1975.

constellations_primary.name: Dismissing the truth
constellations_primary.description: The dismissal of Gough Whitlam by Governor-General Sir John Kerr is one of the most controversial moments in Australian politics. Whitlam’s rebuttal imploring the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ was immortalised on TV and took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy.

end.title: Norman Gunston at Gough Whitlam's dismissal
end.brief_description: Within earshot of the deposed Prime Minister, Gunston improvised a mock-serious question that took the pulse of a nation: “…is this an affront to the Constitution of this country or…just a stroke of good luck for Mr Fraser?”.

constellations_other.name: Dismissing the truth
constellations_other.description: The dismissal of Gough Whitlam by Governor-General Sir John Kerr is one of the most controversial moments in Australian politics. Whitlam’s rebuttal imploring the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ was immortalised on TV and took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy.

links.description: Among the throngs gathered outside Parliament House as events unfolded was TV personality Norman Gunston – the satirical alter ego of Garry McDonald – who added surreal elements to the proceedings when he attempted to elicit comments from Labor personalities.

start.title: Norman Gunston at Gough Whitlam's dismissal
start.brief_description: Within earshot of the deposed Prime Minister, Gunston improvised a mock-serious question that took the pulse of a nation: “…is this an affront to the Constitution of this country or…just a stroke of good luck for Mr Fraser?”.

end.title: Zelig
end.brief_description: A fictional documentary about the life of human chameleon Leonard Zelig, a man who becomes a celebrity in the 1920s due to his ability to look and act like whoever is around him.

constellations_other.name: Dismissing the truth
constellations_other.description: The dismissal of Gough Whitlam by Governor-General Sir John Kerr is one of the most controversial moments in Australian politics. Whitlam’s rebuttal imploring the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ was immortalised on TV and took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy.

links.description: Woody Allen and cinematographer Gordon Willis inserted their own fictional character, Leonard Zelig, into historical proceedings using blue screen technology. Combining scratched and aged footage with 1920s and 30s newsreel, they created a faux documentary that interrogated American society and individuality.

end.title: Jordan Peele's fake news PSA with Barack Obama
end.brief_description: Jordan Peele turned his humour and filmmaking skills to creating a deepfake video of Barack Obama to draw attention to the dangers of the technology.

constellations_other.name: Dismissing the truth
constellations_other.description: The dismissal of Gough Whitlam by Governor-General Sir John Kerr is one of the most controversial moments in Australian politics. Whitlam’s rebuttal imploring the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ was immortalised on TV and took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy.

links.description: In a sobering example of how Deepfakes can create alternate realities, director Jordan Peele created a PSA from Barack Obama, seemingly making contentious comments. The video draws attention to the potential for AI to generate fake videos that could spread disinformation.

start.title: Jordan Peele's fake news PSA with Barack Obama
start.brief_description: Jordan Peele turned his humour and filmmaking skills to creating a deepfake video of Barack Obama to draw attention to the dangers of the technology.

constellations_other.name: Dismissing the truth
constellations_other.description: The dismissal of Gough Whitlam by Governor-General Sir John Kerr is one of the most controversial moments in Australian politics. Whitlam’s rebuttal imploring the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ was immortalised on TV and took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy.

links.description: In Wearing Gillian, Wearing used deepfake and AI technology to map her own face onto volunteers who replied to a newspaper ad. The film asks us to question the tensions of living in an increasingly media-saturated world and how reality can be easily distorted.
